Green Fast Food Posted by admin August 7, 2009 [vms=7695]
BERKELEY, Calif.—Amanda West is the woman behind one of Berkeley’s newest restaurants, Amanda’s Feel Good Fast Food.
It’s a twist on the conventional burgers and fries joint.
Using all natural beef for the burgers, baking the fries instead of frying them and freshly made sodas with organic agave nectar.
The focus is on healthy foods to feed your stomach, and eco-friendly business practices to nourish your soul.
“Every decision we make in this community is about creating a healthy community and that’s from a healthy menu, and that’s also from a healthy environment,”says West.
Which is why West takes special pride in her trash room.
She says,“85% of our waste is either recycled in the blue or composted in the green. This is the trash, little trash bin, and in the corner is the grease that’s recycled.”
Everything they sell is compostable and while all this may sound expensive amanda has a recipe to keep costs down.
“We’re focused on keeping a pretty simple menu and just doing lunch and dinner and just getting as many people though the door as we can,”says Amanda.
Amanda’s is just one of several Bay Area restaurants delivering healthy organic food in an eco-friendly restaurant.
Sellar’s Market in San Francisco uses the same business model.
“It’s a good alternative and it’s just as cheap as McDonalds and so it’s not like you’re paying more for going green which I think is really helpful,”says customer Mary Taloff.
It’s that mindset that these Bay area restaurants are banking on to take a bite out of the traditional fast food market.
Amanda West hopes to expand her restaurant beyond Berkeley in the future. Uncategorized If you enjoyed this post, please consider leaving a comment or subscribe to the feed and get future articles delivered to your feed reader or email.
